meta_data.title: The Kindness One
meta_data.subtitle: Galatians 5:22-23 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Music by

transcription_data.text: Hey, my friends, it's Matt. This is the 10 Minute Bible Hour podcast, and this might be a weird episode. We're talking about kindness. We're up to kindness as a fruit of the spirit in Galatians chapter 5. We're talking about all of this stuff that Paul is listing out as kind of his constructive proposal here at the end of the book to be like, all right, we talked about everything y'all are getting wrong. What does it look like to get it right? So if on the one hand, the basic approach that everybody takes to everything in life to get and everything you want is the power of the flesh, the body, your life, your physical body and your own effort, but Paul is saying through the course of Galatians, this life by the spirit thing is where it's actually at. This is what deliverance from outside the system looks like, and this is what sustenance from outside the system looks like. It's from God. It's from the presence of God in our lives. And yeah, it's a complex idea. And yeah, it can be kind of intimidating to think about it. And yeah, it's kind of freaky to imagine sort of taking your hands off the wheel a little bit. The idea of the spirit being kind of in charge and leading us through life with God, but that's what it is. So in the course of Paul fleshing out what that looks like, he's given us this list of the attributes, the stuff from God that grows in us as we walk by the spirits. We got love, we got joy, we got peace, we got patience. Now we got kindness. And just like every other word on this list so far, there are two meanings here. One meaning is whatever the Bible means when it says it. And the other meaning is whatever it means at any given moment in any given culture as people are currently using it. So what's the deal with kindness? Well, let's work that through. I would like to tell you the brief story of my relationship with a pop song. And this is the part that I think you might get weird. Maybe it'll work. We're fixing to find out when I got done being a pastor at this church in Western Wyoming that I was at for a long time. It was a great experience. It started great. It middled great. It ended great. It was just great. I miss the people. I miss the church. I don't know that I'm ever going to do work like that again because it is murder on your heart when you move on from that. I mean, maybe it's a different kind of heart murder when you move on under bad circumstances because you're stewing about stuff all the time. But I can't even cook up reasons to be mad about that, to craft some narrative, to make me feel better about not living there and not going to that church anymore. There's just nothing to be mad about. The people were amazing. We did something weird and cool and orthodox and great that I love that I got to be a part of and I love that I got to raise my kids for half of their childhood in that context. I do miss the town and I do miss the people, but also, hey, chapters in life, right, bro? Sometimes you turn the page. It's time for the next thing. That's what happened there. It was hard for me on a lot of levels. I hinted at it earlier, I guess. I don't know that I'm going to ever do that kind of work again. Part of the reason that I don't know that I'm going to do it is because I can't stand a leave and that still sticks with me. So I'm in the process of grieving several years ago a choice that I made to move on from a church and a bunch of people who I really care about. You don't really get to take most of those relationships with you when you go as a pastor. You kind of get out of the way and the next person grabs the reins and needs to occupy that role socially and spiritually and all of that stuff. So many people made an effort with me. I appreciate that too, but still, it was lonely as we were leaving, packing up stuff and moving to Rapid City, South Dakota. Rapid City seemed like the right place to go. It's my ancestral home, my mom and my grandparents are from here, my dad and my grandparents on his side and beyond are from here. They met a few miles down the road at college. Mom graduated from high school here. I mean, there's just all this history here. So we ended up in Rapid City and that was cool. And here I am, just me and the internet, my family making new friends. And at that time, politics were incredibly stupid. I'm not saying they're particularly smart now either, but it's just been a rough stretch, my friends, right? Can we say that a politically and just admit this has been a real weird stretch. Our brains weren't ready. Our hearts weren't ready. Humanity wasn't ready for social media and the internet and all of the power that has come with it. This is the weirdest time ever in history. We've got some stuff right. It's been pretty clunky too. I think everybody's heart hurts in very new unprecedented ways right now because of the very devices that we're unwilling to part ways with, the very devices that make our reality work also injure us. They also deaden some beautiful part of us that I think we miss, especially if you're old enough to remember the time before all of this. And our weirdness with the internet is bled over and it's manifesting in our politics and we're not great to each other. And this is where it comes back around to this idea of kindness and in particular this pop song that came onto my radar about the time that I was leaving lander during a time of turmoil in the world and moving to Rapid City, South Dakota and starting up this podcast. And somewhere in there I come across to this song that feels like it was written by somebody who's kind of going through some of the same stuff I was. It's a dude named Frank Turner. I don't know much about him other than I like his voice. It's just sort of innocent and sweet and gentle. And yeah, there's a softness and a kindness to it that I really appreciate. You wrote this song called Be More Kind. I think it probably came out in 2019 or 2020. Maybe it's older than that. I don't know. I didn't check the timeline on it. This story is basically true even if my chronology isn't exactly perfect. And so I have a pretty tender heart at that point anyway. And along comes this little Frank Turner song. And the song is about him feeling anxiety about the future and what's coming up next. And him feeling kind of shaken about what he understood the world to be when he was a kid and how things are turning out. And I don't know if he and I think many of the same things politically or if we thought the same things then are different now. I have no idea. What I know is the song is very heartfelt. It's very genuine. It's very kind. And indeed, the chorus is just about exactly that. It gets the chorus and he just sings his gentle thing. You know, a world that has decided that it's going to lose its mind. Be more kind, my friends. Try to be more kind, except it sounds good when he sings it and it sounds very honest and very sincere. And I listened to that at one point and I just balled over it and it struck a chord. You know what it's like. I sometimes a song will just strike a chord with you just perfectly. That doesn't make me cry every time I hear it now. But yeah, at the time that it was very moving to me, I was so in the mood for kindness. I missed the warmth and the kindness of the community of faith I had been a part of that I voluntarily chose to leave. It was kind of kicking myself like, yeah, what are you doing here, man? That's hard to replace, dude. He sure. And then the world was crazy and maybe still is a little bit and it was just heavy. And I appreciated this simple plea for kindness. Now, look, I know people mean different things when they say kind right now. A lot of times kindness or like people need to just be nicer. They need to be kinder is code for I think your politics are unkind and mean. I think my politics are kind. Therefore, I want kindness and by that, I mean, you should like my politics. I know that some people use it in kind of that not self-aware juvenile, even emotionally manipulative way. But I'm not talking about that. I felt like this song, at least the way I chose to listen to it, squared with what I catch when I see words like kindness in the Bible, list like in the fruit of the spirit. And when I see that idea of kindness in the Bible, to me, one of the attached virtues that goes along with that is the self-awareness, awareness of one's own circumstances. I mean, what is kindness born out of, right? Empathy to some degree. And again, not empathy the way it's sometimes cheaply and emotionally, manipulatively used now, but I mean, like real empathy, like the kind of thing where you look at another person, you're like, hey, you kind of made the same stuff I am. And I can kind of imagine what it would be like to be you. And that makes me care about how things work out for you. And it might even make me do something here or there, just show an extra degree of consideration. It's sort of from the same family tree of virtue as being patient and being forgiving, right? Ah, I need to be forgiven for stuff. So I can imagine what it's like to get things wrong and really genuinely feel embarrassed and bad about it and wish I could take something back to feel ashamed of my lack of social sense or self-awareness and just want people to see the little boy inside who's trying to get things right and would really like to help people and would really like to be liked by other people. I can imagine what that feels like for me and I can kind of see it on you. So it results in kindness. To me, it seems like so much of kindness in the truest sense just flows out of that awareness that you're dealing with people who are made in the image of God, who are also subject to the fall of humanity, maybe screwed up in some different ways than I'm screwed up, but probably screwed up in some of the same ways I'm screwed up, equally in need of a deliverer and a savior that is from beyond the power of the flesh. And I guess when I see kindness at its best in people I admire, that's what it's born out of. And eyes wide open kind of awareness and alertness to other people of valuing of other people, a cherishing of what has been given to them that makes them want that same thing to be given to other people, even strangers. And I thought Frank Turner in this little song that I hope you will go and check out for yourself, I thought that he did a nice job of capturing that feeling, that sense. Lyrically, yeah, probably tonally. Yeah, big time I felt that from him. And at least for me and where I was when I first encountered it, I felt like this Frank Turner fellow, someone about whom I know basically nothing, did a nice job of capturing that tone, that heart of kindness as I understand it from the Bible, and that grace filled core out of which true kindness flows told you this was going to be a weird one. You're also gracious. You're also kind to take the version of me that you get on a daily podcast because overwhelmingly this does happen in real time. So where my head is at is what we do together as we work through this. So thanks for understanding me. And also I get the impression you give a rip about me. Thanks for caring about me and my family too. I really appreciate that. I hope you can tell that even over the distance, I feel the same way about you. I think that's good for now. I'm Matt. This is the 10 minute Bible hour podcast. Let's do this again soon.
